title: Eddie Hearn claims Tyson Fury is 'packing up boxing' amid his move into WWE and Christmas single
text:
Tyson Fury has lost his head and doesn't have the hunger to compete at the top level for heavyweight titles, according to Eddie Hearn.

The 31-year-old from Manchester has seen a potential rematch with WBC champion Deontay Wilder disappear and has instead decided to dip his toes into the world of WWE wrestling.

Fury is keeping himself busy going into the new year, taking on Braun Strowman at Crown Jewel on October 31, reportedly netting him £12million, while he is also set to record a Christmas single with pop star Robbie Williams.

Tyson Fury is grabbing all the headlines as he fights in the WWE and records a Christmas single

But while Fury revels in the fame and the headlines, Matchroom boss Eddie Hearn feels that he is 'packing up boxing' and wants to enjoy his life instead.

'Listen Tyson's [Fury] on a roll right now, he's going for it,' he said, speaking to IFL TV.

'He's got a Christmas single coming out, he's doing WWE wrestling - his heads gone completely but he's absolutely living life, so good luck to him.

Matchroom boss Eddie Hearn feels Fury's head has gone and doesn't have the hunger to fight

'I think he's packing up boxing, I really think that he's looking at it and thinking, "I've made a nice few quid over the last few fights, I'm enjoying life".'

On Friday, Fury announced his team-up with Robbie Williams as the pair attempt to become Christmas No 1 this year.

Williams will be releasing a festive album and Fury will appear on a track called Bad Sharon.

But Hearn believes that Fury prefers the 'other world' of publicity and instead of getting into a scrap in the ring, and said the Fury that beat Wladimir Klitschko to become unified world champion had more focus.

It’s happening guys Christmas #1 pic.twitter.com/xbaHZhJVRW — TYSON FURY (@Tyson_Fury) October 18, 2019

He added: 'I just think he's looking at this other world and going, "Do you know what, this is a lot more fun than getting my head punched and going into camp". I'm sure he'll fight again but I don't think he's got the hunger.

'It's hard, look, all of a sudden he's earned some great money, he's prancing around in Los Angeles getting in the ring doing all this cringey stuff with the WWE guys, everyone's loving it - it's brilliant for him.

'He's got the Robbie Williams thing, good luck to him.

'I don’t believe he has the same hunger, that he had, well certainly pre-Klitschko, but even pre-Wilder. As long as he's happy and healthy good luck to him, I think he's hilarious.'

Fury's last fight was in Las Vegas against Otto Wallin, who he beat via unanimous decision, although he suffered some nasty facial wounds.

Last December he challenged Wilder for his WBC strap and survived two knockdowns to claim a draw, although many believe the British heavyweight should have won on points.
description: The 31-year-old from Manchester has seen a potential rematch with WBC champion Deontay Wilder disappear and has instead decided to dip his toes into the world of WWE wrestling.
